data.title: merged old and new PolygonRegionLoader
data.body: Didn't want to break API with my second PR, but since you agreed in #1602, I do it in the third.

data.title: TextureData refactoring and mipmaps
data.body:
Refactored:
- TextureData to handle Pixmap and Custom TextureType
- TextureData consumeCompressedData to consumeCustomData
- GLTexture function to uploadImageData to custom mipmap level

Added:
-MipMapTextureData which handles multiple TextureData to be uploaded to single mipmpa levels

data.title: Call LoadedCallback when asset is loaded in AssetManager
data.body:
Right now, if you try to load an asset already loaded by the AssetManager, passing along AssetParameters with a loadedCallback, loadedCallback is never called.

It seems reasonable that, since the asset is already loaded, loadedCallback is called right away. This PR modifies AssetManager to introduce this change.

data.title: Java 7 support in LibGDX
data.body:
Seeing as the Android SDK supports Java 7 language features with it's Gradle based build system [1] and RoboVM requires a OpenJDK 1.7 to even compile a project[2], what's stopping LibGDX from utilising the language features from Java 7 at the same level of the Android compiler (everything except try-with-resources)? 

The only reason I'm asking is that it'd be kinda nice to have the option of using multi-catch and the diamond operator pattern to remove some of the verbosity in generics and exceptions. Especially as my normal development on Java and Android is already using these patterns in my code.

[1]http://tools.android.com/tech-docs/new-build-system/user-guide#TOC-Using-sourceCompatibility-1.7
[2]http://www.robovm.org/docs

data.title: Using Viewport forces a call to Gdx.gl.glViewport
data.body: When using a Stage, the usage of Viewport forces a call to Gdx.gl.glViewport due to the update() method. This unnecessarily couples the OpenGL actual rendering surface to the Stage's virtual camera. With 0.9.9 and earlier versions, it was possible to use multiple stages without their updates causing the glViewport to change.

data.title: Removed loads of warnings.
data.body: As per @NathanSweet 's request https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/commit/e5ceac2310626bad714be3ec7ee725fd0f6159ba#commitcomment-5944213

data.title: Fixed perfect reflection on collision
data.body: I think DKoding is right. See http://www.badlogicgames.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=17&t=13577

data.title: SpotLight per vertex lightning
data.body:
Here is an implementation for **SpotLight** in the default shader and with an example.

According to the OpenGl standart, this light includes the attentuation (constant, linear, quadratic) and the cutoff and exponent.
Because shader are currently on per-pixel lightning, the cutoff can be not so nice, _but a per-fragment lightning is being studied_. I'm not at all a shader master, so any recommendation, suggestion, change or whatever would be appreciated.
I'm also here to answer any questions if you have some.

Strange issue with Actions.run
data.body: Information and code snippets on how to reproduce here: http://www.badlogicgames.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=13562

data.title: Various small (mostly math) changes
data.body:
Some relatively small changes:
- DefaultRenderableSorter: fix rare floating point error by casting to int.
- Intersector: add intersectRayBoundsFast(ray, center, dimensions); (not requiring a BoundingBox instance).
- Matrix4: add getScale<axis>Squared and getScale<axis>
- Vector2: add some static helper methods
- Vector3: add methods to unrotate and untransform (I'm not sure about the naming of the latter).
- Ran the formatter

GWT untested

data.title: Music loop
data.body:
Hello guyz,

My first libgdx game is almost finished. I'll release it on web, facebook and Android. But I've noticed an issue with the musics :
when i play a music in loop, it doesn't loop properly.
- On the web version (expecially on firefox) there is a gap of few milliseconds before the music restart at the beginning. Ok, i guess it's a problem of HTML5, sound player, bla bla and it's not totally perfect for the moment. Yeah ?
- BUT the main problem is on Android : when the music ends and loops to the beginning, it's the opposite issue of the web issue ! the music don't play till the end of the file, so few milliseconds of music are missing. In other words, the loop comes to quickly

Somebody has already dealed with this ? Is it an issue of Android or libgdx ? ...me ? (well i juste use three lines of code to loop the music)

Sorry for the approximate english (i'm french).

Thxxx ;)

data.title: AndroidApplication and AndroidGraphics classes refactoring
data.body:
This refactoring doesn't change the API and makes good code reuse improving maintenance.
I've tried to make small incremental commits to make your review easier.

Relevant changes:
- Now ALL AndroidApplication\* classes implement the AndroidApplicationBase interface
- Each AndroidApplication\* class uses a lifecycle listener (if needed) specialized for audio management.
- AndroidGraphics is now used as-is by activity, fragment and daydream applications.
- AndroidLiveWallpaper has its own extension of AndroidGraphics. Since the original AndroidLiveWallpaper is a bit nasty, I've preferred to grab and override main methods of the superclass AndroidGraphics so to minimize the impact and avoid breaking existing stuff.

data.title: Low framerate (25 instead of 60) on Android 2.3.6 (maybe other versions too)
data.body: Wher i start or pause/resume every app which is using libgdx its starting often at 25fps instead of 60fps. Im not sure how often it is but i guess its just random so ill just say 50/50. I have created a thread on StackOverflow here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/22913391/libgdx-often-low-fps-after-android-device-resume so you can check other details of this problem there. I've also created a movie which is showing this issue really well https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YjMr9fBYhHA&feature=youtu.be

data.body:
This is highly recommended by the Android project.
http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/graphics/opengl.html

data.title: *.jar files are not ignored by default
data.body:
This caused gradle-wrapper.jar to not be included in the project repo thus defying the whole purpose of using gradlew.
Also needed for libraries that still need to be added manually.

data.title: Minor error in ReflectionTest
data.body:
Hey I just started with libgdx and it's been great so far! Anyway, while checking out the tests I came over a small bug in ReflectionTest, where it threw an exception with the following message:

```
FAILED: Method not found: mul, for class: com.badlogic.gdx.math.Vector2 [...]
```

It's probably just because of refactoring, but anyway, I found that if I replaced the second parameter on line 57 from "mul" to "scl":

```
Method mMul = ClassReflection.getMethod(Vector2.class, "scl", float.class);
```

It would run as intended :)

Thanks. Karakaz out

data.title: Created generic KeyFrames class based on g2d Animation class.
data.body:
This extends the functionality of the Animation class to objects
other than TextureRegion by introducing a new class KeyFrames<T>. The
Animation class remains as an implementation of KeyFrames<TextureRegion>.

I've often found myself reimplementing the functionality of the Animation class to keep track of other things over a period of frames, e.g. collision during an animation, so I thought maybe this generic class would be helpful to other people as well. It should be backwards compatible except for the PlayMode enum moving to KeyFrames.

Let me know if this is acceptable and I'll fill out the CLA.

Thanks!

data.title: Guess Android SDK location
data.body: in both gui and cli

data.title: obj groups are essentially nodes in libgdx
data.body: When the ObjLoader loads the groups from a .obj file, the group names are not used, but ignored and replaced by generated names. How would groups be found back as nodes in a model without their names?

data.title: Glitch after unloading TextureAtlas using AssetManager
data.body:
EDIT: So basically it was my programming fault that I did not dispose all references.
I still wonder that there is no error message and it's a valid behavior to unload a sprite sheet while and it still can be used. On Android for example I did not even unload files (see above) to make this glitch appear.
LibGDX checks pretty much every parameter (e.g. calling glEnd before glBegin) so I did not expect this behavior.
If this is the correct behavior I must apologize by having wasted your time.

---

Original post:
Hey!

Maybe I found a bug or there should be an error message (or it is my programming fault)

The sprites get not rendered, only the blending color after I do the following.
![loading issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/801818/2625405/716713be-bd94-11e3-93dd-0179ec2eede6.png)

if I do this (not directly after each other):
1. Load: load("spritesheet.txt", TextureAtlas.class);
2. unload: unload("spritesheet.txt");
3. load again: load("spritesheet.txt", TextureAtlas.class);

The same happens on android without unloading but leaving and then reentering the game.

I may post some more information how to reproduce it later today.
I change the sprite sheets betweens levels so I should unload the old ones (into needed any more) and I also managed to archive this bug with some sprites being rendered and some not.

data.title: Aliasing effects by using FitViewport
data.body:
After integrating the Viewport classes in libgdx I integrated the FitViewport in my game. But the scaling of the FitViewport causes aliasing effects which wasn't the case when I ensured keeping the aspect ratio of the screen myself.
Below you can see an example (on the left: game using FitViewport; on the right: old Viewport management). It's most noticeable when you look at the "v 0.0.15" label or at the audio buttons. Just ignore the differing button sizes.
What can I do against it? I appreciate any help.

![fitviewport aliasing](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5825645/2625197/1c8f52f2-bd85-11e3-99d0-90fb5a31e4c3.png)
